programme.title: The Ellen DeGeneres Show
programme.desc: Ellen welcomes LaShandria Williamson and her 22-year-old son, Shakir Aquil, from Atlanta, GA. Shakir is an army sergeant and he has not seen his mom in two years due to being stationed in Virginia and deployed to South Korea. LaShandria is a former Atlanta police officer, who currently works as a resource officer at Therrell High School. Last week, Shakir surprised LaShandria during a pep rally at her school and the video of their reunion has gained national attention. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Earth Odyssey With Dylan Dreyer
programme.desc: Today on Earth Odyssey, we head back to South America to visit some of our favorite animals. We'll start in Venezuela, where the Orinoco River provides a home for people and animals – such as pumas, egrets and crocodiles. We'll also head to the Amazon rainforest where life is bursting at every turn. From red howler monkeys to harpy eagles, the Amazon rainforest provides us with some of the most fascinating animals on Earth. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Roots Less Traveled
programme.desc: Host Faruq Tauheed takes the 80-year-old dancing grandpa and grandson Evan and Scott to Billings, Montana. They learn that Evan's great-grandfather was an integral part of the U.S. western states expansion of 1862 and had cultivated a 160-acre farm. But closer to Evan's heart, he learns that two of his uncles, who he met when he was a child, were prisoners of war in WWII and both received Purple Hearts. After they deeply connect, the two dance at a western hall. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Earth Odyssey With Dylan Dreyer
programme.desc: Today on Earth Odyssey, we head back to South America to visit some of our favorite animals. We'll start in Venezuela, where the Orinoco River provides a home for people and animals – such as pumas, egrets and crocodiles. We'll also head to the Amazon rainforest where life is bursting at every turn. programme.title: Roots Less Traveled
programme.desc: Host Faruq Tauheed takes the 80-year-old dancing grandpa and grandson Evan and Scott to Billings, Montana. They learn that Evan's great-grandfather was an integral part of the U.S. western states expansion of 1862 and had cultivated a 160-acre farm. But closer to Evan's heart, he learns that two of his uncles, who he met when he was a child, were prisoners of war in WWII and both received Purple Hearts. After they deeply connect, the two dance at a western hall. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: The Champion Within *
programme.desc: We hitch a ride with driver Jimmie Johnson and go behind the curtains of the man behind the wheel. Then, we learn how breakout football star George Kittle's big personality helps him shine in the biggest moments. Then, we are brought along on a journey to experience how golf can change a life. Plus, we meet Jesselyn Silva, who might be smaller than the average boxer, but her hard work and technique make her boxing's next big thing. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Earth Odyssey With Dylan Dreyer
programme.desc: Today on Earth Odyssey, we head back to South America to visit some of our favorite animals. We'll start in Venezuela, where the Orinoco River provides a home for people and animals – such as pumas, egrets and crocodiles. We'll also head to the Amazon rainforest where life is bursting at every turn. From red howler monkeys to harpy eagles, the Amazon rainforest provides us with some of the most fascinating animals on Earth. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Consumer 101

And, with the help of a Consumer Reports expert, Jack learns all about choosing the right mattress to help get a good night's sleep. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Roots Less Traveled
programme.desc: Host Faruq Tauheed takes the 80-year-old dancing grandpa and grandson Evan and Scott to Billings, Montana. They learn that Evan's great-grandfather was an integral part of the U.S. western states expansion of 1862 and had cultivated a 160-acre farm. But closer to Evan's heart, he learns that two of his uncles, who he met when he was a child, were prisoners of war in WWII and both received Purple Hearts. After they deeply connect, the two dance at a western hall. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Vets Saving Pets *
programme.desc: Dr. Debbie James finds herself helping a cat named Micah who's beginning to exhibit signs of paralysis in his hind legs. Dr. James suspects an issue along the spine, which might mean an invasive surgery for the poor feline. Then, after a brave cat named Jerry survives a house fire, his gums suffer from smoke inhalation. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Roots Less Traveled
programme.desc: Host Faruq Tauheed takes the 80-year-old dancing grandpa and grandson Evan and Scott to Billings, Montana. They learn that Evan's great-grandfather was an integral part of the U.S. western states expansion of 1862 and had cultivated a 160-acre farm. But closer to Evan's heart, he learns that two of his uncles, who he met when he was a child, were prisoners of war in WWII and both received Purple Hearts. After they deeply connect, the two dance at a western hall. (repeat) (cc).(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled `Password Plus' and `Super Password.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Password Plus

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Password

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Supermarket Sweep
programme.desc: Contestants at a supermarket rush to fill their carts with as many items as possible and, in a bonus round, find hidden cash. The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Password Plus

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

The original version, which was taped at actual supermarkets, aired on ABC from 1965 to 1967. The revival, which began in 1990, first aired on Lifetime before moving to PAX. (cc).(n)

programme.title: Split Second
programme.desc: Contestants answer questions based on a series of clues. At the close of each show, the day's winner earned a chance to win an car: If they turned the key and it started, it was theirs. The series ran initially on ABC with Tom Kennedy from 1972 to '75. Monty Hall emceed the 1986-87 syndicated version.(n)

programme.title: Blockbusters
programme.desc: A player competes against a pair of family members answering trivia questions in a race to connect a path across a game board.(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Match Game
programme.desc: `Dumb Dora was so dumb that...' is a typical lead-in to `fill-in-the-blank'-style queries asked of contestants seeking to match celebrities' answers. This game show had several incarnations on network TV and in syndication, but throughout it was noted for the double-entendre humor and in-joking byplay among its celebrity panelists, including Charles Nelson Reilly and Richard Dawson (in a stint that launched his kissy-kissy `Family Feud' career).(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Classic Concentration
programme.desc: Two contestants must face a computer-generated board of 25 squares.(n)

programme.title: Password
programme.desc: A Goodson-Todman classic in which celebrity-contestant teams compete in a word-association game, with each player giving only one-word clues. Subsequent versions of the show were titled `Password Plus' and `Super Password.(n)

programme.title: Password Plus
programme.desc: Contestants---including celebrities---compete for cash prizes in an updated version of the classic game show.(n)

programme.title: Super Password
programme.desc: A new edition of the game, featuring jackpots worth thousands of dollars, and a `cash word,' worth $1000 or more for guessing a single word.(n)

programme.title: Tattletales
programme.desc: Celebrities and their spouses tried to match answers to host Bert Convy's questions on this game show. While one spouse sat backstage (and out of earshot), the other would answer the host's questions. Then the offstage player would give their response while sitting before a monitor.(n)

programme.title: Press Your Luck
programme.desc: Players answer questions to earn `spins' on a giant board in this daytime favorite from the 1980s. What they want, of course, is cash, merchandise or vacations, but, to use the series catchphrase, `no whammys,' which would mean watching a cartoon ogre confiscate all their swag. The format was later revived by the Game Show Network during the 2002-03 season.(n)

programme.title: Card Sharks
programme.desc: Contestants guess whether high or low cards from a deck will be revealed in a popular game show that in later versions included contestants predicting the outcome of surveys.(n)

programme.title: Sale of the Century
programme.desc: Three contestants answer rapid-fire, general-knowledge questions for the chance to buy big-ticket items at bargain prices. The winner may keep the prize or risk it the next day for a shot at something better.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered. In 1987, the series was resurrected as `Classic Concentration,' with Alex Trebek as host until the show's end in 1994.(n)

programme.title: To Tell the Truth
programme.desc: A contestant with an unusual background and two impostors try to stump a panel in this classic game show. Debuting on CBS Dec. 18, 1956, it left the Eye network on May 22, 1967, but was revived in syndication from 1969 to 1977, then again in 1980-81 and 1990.(n)

programme.title: What's My Line?
programme.desc: One of the classic game shows (and one of the simplest), and the first hit for producers Mark Goodson and Bill Todman (`I've Got a Secret,' `To Tell the Truth'). The panelists had to guess contestants' odd or not-so-odd jobs, then (while blindfolded) guess a celebrity guest's identity (New York Yankee Phil Rizzuto was the first). After its 17-year CBS run, `Line' aired for another seven in syndication. Panelist Arlene Francis stuck it out all 24 years.(n)

programme.title: Concentration
programme.desc: One of NBC's longest-running programs, this seminal game show was a daytime staple from 1958 to '73, with forays into prime time in '58 and '61. Of all the emcees who revealed the rebus (Ed McMahon and Bob Clayton among them), Hugh Downs is the one best remembered.
